channel.title: Arrays
channel.description:
From what I know, the String.split(); method returns an array. Each spot is one section of how you separated the String. So let's say I have the string "Hello, world you all suck" I would get the following IF I were to split them using " " (a space) as the parameter. in array arr[]; arr[0] = Hello, arr[1] = world arr[2] = you arr[3] = all arr[4] = suck
Ok now let's say I have an array of arrays to put a set of strings in. I have [i]names[][/i]: names[1] = Bob Bill names[2] = Chris Tart names[3] = Sonny Delight
now what I was trying to do was the following: [code] for (int i = 0; i<names.length; i++) { String split[][] = new String[names.length][names.length]; String split[i][] = names[i].split(" "); } [/code]
Basically put all the names into one of array that contains each array of the names. So in split[1][1] would be the first word of the 1st name. That being Bob. but yeah, as you all probably know my code doesn't work. Any help is appreciated and yes I did google, didn't help me much. Oh and please try to explain and not just answer.. thank you

item.title: Arrays
item.dc:creator: @system system
item.description:
@system wrote:

Unhandled:

While this may not be applicable to your problem, you might want to look at Hashtable<K, V>. No need for a fixed size.

Thanks

[quote=“Yz85Racer, post:16, topic:250868”][quote author=IScrubs link=topic=330967.msg2584532#msg2584532 date=1229404202]
Ok and as you said before about making the second dimension of the array like 3-4 or w/e… would it be really wrong against like the holy bible of java or making extra space doesn’t really affect anything?
[/quote]
…I can’t imagine iterating through a few array elements are going to cause you any memory problems, provided you don’t do it stupidly.[/quote]

I meant as in is it better no to or it doesn’t really matter. Now I see it doesn’t… thanks

Read full topic

While this may not be applicable to your problem, you might want to look at Hashtable<K, V>. No need for a fixed size.

item.title: Arrays
item.dc:creator: @BAsh BAsh
item.description:
@BAsh wrote:

A [][] is an array of an array. This the small but crucial difference between the c/c++ version and java’s.

  • c/c++/others use an array and then some math to convert the two indexes into a single index of the array it self.
  • java have an array of objects. These objects are arrays but these single dimension arrays are not of a fixed size.
    This means that the second dimension’s size can vary depending on the index in the first dimension.

I did not know that you could create an array that way. Since the bytecode requires a number i assume it is filled in with a 0.

Read full topic

item.title: Arrays
item.dc:creator: @system system
item.description:
@system wrote:

[quote=“BAsh, post:12, topic:250868”][quote author=Pwnd link=topic=330967.msg2584535#msg2584535 date=1229404328]
I’m really tired, sorry. I fucked that up.

String[][] split = new String[names.length - 1][]; for (.....) { split[i] = names[i].split(" "); }

And it does use extra memory, as far as I would know (Since I’m just an idiot giving advice atm :P)

Edit: part of my code wasn’t showing up and I blame SMF because of it.
[/quote]
good but “String[][] split = new String[names.length - 1][];” should be “String[][] split = new String[names.length - 1][0];”[/quote]

Wouldn’t that make all the second dimensions of the array have only one spot? I think leaving it empty would make it so that when I do put something in there, it makes it exactly the size needed.

Read full topic

item.title: Arrays
item.dc:creator: @Pwnd Pwnd
item.description:
@Pwnd wrote:

for (…) {
String[] items = names.split(" ");
split[i][items.length - 1] = items;
}

I think.

Edit:
Or just split[i] = names[i].split(" "); instead of figuring the length.

Read full topic

item.title: Arrays
item.dc:creator: @system system
item.description:
@system wrote:

it worked thanks.

That was another question: how can I make it so that the size of the second dimension of the array is exactly what it needs to be (the size of the strings in names[])? I can’t think of a way since well aren’t I supposed to set the size of it when I initialize the array?

Read full topic

item.title: Arrays
item.dc:creator: @Pwnd Pwnd
item.description:
@Pwnd wrote:

Well, first off, you keep reinitializing the same array.

String[][] split = new String[names.length][names.length];
for (int i = 0; i<names.length; i++) {
split[i][] = names[i].split(" ");
}

Also, making the second dimension of the array the same length as the list of the names seems inefficient.
You could just make it 3-4 sizes max?

Read full topic

item.title: Arrays
item.dc:creator: @system system
item.description:
@system wrote:

but wouldn’t names[0] count as a spot too? So 0,1,2 would be the same as saying 3 spots?

errors:

MyOwnJavaArrayProject.java:16: ']' expected String split[i][] = names[i].split(" "); ^ MyOwnJavaArrayProject.java:16: illegal start of expression String split[i][] = names[i].split(" "); ^ MyOwnJavaArrayProject.java:16: ';' expected String split[i][] = names[i].split(" "); ^ MyOwnJavaArrayProject.java:16: illegal start of expression String split[i][] = names[i].split(" "); ^ MyOwnJavaArrayProject.java:21: class, interface, or enum expected } ^ 5 errors

gay name i know

and if I were to take out “String” at the second line I would still get this:

MyOwnJavaArrayProject.java:16: illegal start of expression split[i][] = names[i].split(" "); ^ 1 error

Read full topic

item.description:

Btw, since array in Java are 0 base, you’d do [names.length - 1]

item.title: Arrays
item.dc:creator: @system system
item.description:
@system wrote:

From what I know, the String.split(); method returns an array. Each spot is one section of how you separated the String. So let’s say I have the string “Hello, world you all suck” I would get the following IF I were to split them using " " (a space) as the parameter.
in array arr[];
arr[0] = Hello,
arr[1] = world
arr[2] = you
arr[3] = all
arr[4] = suck

Ok now let’s say I have an array of arrays to put a set of strings in. I have names[]:
names[1] = Bob Bill
names[2] = Chris Tart
names[3] = Sonny Delight

now what I was trying to do was the following:

for (int i = 0; i<names.length; i++) {
	String split[][] = new String[names.length][names.length];
	String split[i][] = names[i].split(" ");
	}

Basically put all the names into one of array that contains each array of the names. So in split[1][1] would be the first word of the 1st name. That being Bob. but yeah, as you all probably know my code doesn’t work.
Any help is appreciated and yes I did google, didn’t help me much. Oh and please try to explain and not just answer… thank you

Read full topic
